III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
1

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff are unable to control youth or keep other youth safe in this
youth's presence.
Investigation Interviews:
Complaint Source for this investigation was anonymous.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on April 11,
2024. Youth A reported she does not like the facility because she
feels staff are always in her business. She reported lately there have
been an extra staff working at the facility which frustrates her
because the staff are watching her closer. Youth A reported she does
not losing privileges and when that happens, she will run away from
the home. She reported when she runs away, she goes to the library
so she can use the computers. Youth A reported she started to run
away after she lost privileges for assaulting a peer at school. She
reported staff are just “doing too much” and she wants to be able to
do what she wants on her own. Youth A reported she is aware she
has a safety plan but does not remember what it says.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via phone on April 9, 2024.
Foster Care Worker is Youth A’s primary foster care worker and
noted she is aware of Youth A’s high-risk behaviors. She reported
she has been working closely with the facility, especially with
Program Manager and Clinical Coordinator. Foster Care Worker
reported the facility is going above and beyond to try to keep Youth A
and the other youth safe at the facility. Currently the facility is
providing extra staffing to focus on Youth A’s needs. She stated
Youth A has behaviors that include AWOL and physical aggression
towards others. Foster Care Worker reported Youth A got into a
physical fight with another youth from the facility at school and
currently the facility is keeping the two youth separated as much as
possible. She reported meetings are occurring about finding a more
secure placement for Youth A due to her higher needs. Foster Care
Worker reported the facility is putting in as much support in place to
keep Youth A and the other youth at the facility safe.
Program Manager was interviewed face to face at the facility on
April 11, 2024. Program Manager reported Youth A has been at the
facility since March 13, 2024. She reported the first three weeks
things went well. Program Manager reported Youth A started having
behaviors at school and assaulted Youth D on the school bus on
2

April 2, 2024. She reported since then, Youth A started to show
increased behaviors and constantly AWOL’ed from the facility.
Program Manager reported the team keeps Youth A and Youth D
separated as much as possible due to safety concerns. She reported
there is increased staffing on the unit with either an extra staff
working or an administrative staff on shift for support. She reported
staff are debriefed before each shift to make sure they know updates
on Youth A and her behavior plan. Program Manager reported no
staff is left alone working with Youth A for safety. She reported the
facility does not use a restraint model and uses loss of privileges for
discipline. Program Manager reported their program is an open
residential, so when Youth A leaves the home without permission,
they make sure to verbally encourage her to come back, and if she
leaves, they will call the police. She reported if Youth A has
escalated verbal behavior with the other youth, the staff will call a
clear to make sure the area is safe. A clear is when the other youth
are moved into another area away from Youth A. Due to Youth A’s
behavior and concern for safety, Program Manager has been
working with Youth A’s foster care team, including their upper
management, to find a more supportive and safer placement for
Youth A. She reported a 30-day notice was put in place for Youth A
to move and it was recommended by her foster care team that a
more secure placement is needed.
Clinical Coordinator was interviewed face to face at the facility
on April 11, 2024. Clinical Coordinator reported her role at the
facility to make sure the youth are getting connected with therapy
services and providing crisis therapy. She reported she was called
when Youth A assaulted Youth D on the bus on April 2, 2024. Clinical
Coordinator reported immediately they put into place that staff was to
keep Youth A and Youth D separated due to safety concerns. She
reported when Youth A got back to the facility she was verbally
escalated and AWOLed for the first time from the facility. Clinical
Coordinator reported she stayed at the facility most of the night to
see if Youth A was going to return which she did not. Youth A
returned on April 3, 2024, but left again. She reported she talked with
Youth A on April 4, 2024, and it was found that there were concerns
she may have been sexually assaulted. Clinical Coordinator called
the police once Youth A disclosed. She reported Youth A continues
to escalate with staff and peers when she gets redirected or does not
get her way, and she will AWOL from home. Clinical Coordinator
reported the facility has been adding additional staffing ever since
April 2, 2024, and she has been making sure staff are aware of any
updates on safety planning for Youth A daily. She reported Youth A
has been taken to the hospital for mental health assessment but has
deemed it is all behavioral concerns. Clinical Coordinator reported
Youth A’s foster care team is updated on Youth A’s behaviors and
critical incidents. She reported a 30-day notice request was
3

submitted to move Youth A due to safety concerns with the facility
being an open program.
Youth B and Youth C were separately interviewed face to face at
the facility on April 11, 2024. Youth B and Youth C reported the
staff have been doing their best to keep the youth safe at the facility.
They both reported when they get in trouble, they will lose a privilege
such as TV, going on outings, or can’t get their nails done. Youth B
and Youth C reported Youth A will get upset when she does not get
her way and will yell, throw things, and leave the home. Both youths
reported there has been extra staff working, including administrative
staff since Youth A assaulted Youth D. They both reported the staff
do their best to keep the youth separated and will request a clear
when Youth A’s behaviors get escalated.
Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3 were separately interviewed face to
face at the facility on April 11, 2024. Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3
reported Youth A’s behaviors have increased since April 2, 2024,
after she assaulted Youth D on the school bus. They reported
increased staffing on each shift to provide support due to Youth A’s
behaviors and the safety of the other youth. No staff can be alone
with Youth A due to safety and staff are to keep Youth A and Youth D
separated as much as possible. Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3 all
reported concerns about Youth A’s AWOL behavior and the risk she
puts herself into when she AWOLs. They reported before each shift
they get debriefed on any updates on Youth A's behavior plan and
safety. It was reported staff are trained to redirect negative behavior,
use verbal de-escalation, and follow through with a loss of privilege
when a youth earns a consequence. They reported when a youth
AWOLs, they are to try to verbally redirect them back into the home
and if that does not work, the police will need to be called. Staff 1,
Staff 2, and Staff 3 reported they can always call on-call
administration when needed. They reported if there is no extra staff
to work, then someone from the administrative team will fill in. Staff 1,
Staff 2, and Staff 3 reported they feel supported by the administration
team and report there has been clear communication on safety
planning on the unit.
Documentation Reviewed:
- Girlstown Staffing Ratio Policy dated October 2023- Ratio
policy notes there is a minimum of one staff to every four
youth during waking hours and one to twelve during sleeping
hours. The policy does note the ratio can also be based on
the need of the youth. The facility followed their ratio policy
and increased staffing support due to Youth A’s high needs.
- Extra Staffing provided since April 2, 2024- Program
Manager provided a list of staff who worked since Youth A
was in a physical fight with Youth D. The facility has had at
4

least one additional staff scheduled during the day and
overnight to provide additional support for Youth A.
- Youth A’s File- Documentation was reviewed from Youth A’s
file at the facility about Youth A’s behaviors, incidents and
clinical assessments. There was also a safety plan that was
completed with the facility and Foster Care worker for Youth
A. The staff that were interviewed were aware of all these
documents. Within Youth A’s file there was a request to move
Youth A from the facility due to Youth A’s increased behaviors
that was completed on April 3, 2024, by Program Manager.
- Facility Program Statement- The program statement notes
the facility is a non-secure residential program and staff are to
use non-violent crisis intervention approaches.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as the facility provided for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of the youth served.
Within interviews and documentation reviewed additional staffing
was provided to help support Youth A’s behaviors and the facility
developed and communicated safety plan.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
